small.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: not large in size or amount
small.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The T-shirt was too small for him.
The sweater comes in three sizes – small, medium, and large.
Only a relatively small number of people were affected.
A much smaller proportion of women are employed in senior positions.
small.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a small problem, job, mistake etc is not important or does not have a large effect
small.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: We may have to make a few small changes.
There’s only a small difference between them.
It was good to feel we had helped in some small way.
small.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I’ve known him since he was a small boy.
small.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: small letters are letters in the form a, b, c etc rather than A, B, C etc
small.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a small voice is quiet and soft
small.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: ‘What about me?’ she asked in a small voice.
small.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1: They live in a nice small town
They live in a small nice town
small.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2: She had a small white dog
She had a white small dog
small.translation[0].note_box[1].section: not large in size, amount, or effect
small – used about objects, places, and living things. Used especially with other adjectives to show how you feel about someone or something
It’s a very pretty little town.
The poor little dog has hurt its leg.
The cake was decorated with little flowers.
used about prices, rents, levels, or standards
People on low incomes are finding it difficult to pay fuel bills.
The crime rate in the area is relatively low.
small and not very important or not very noticeable
There’s been a slight improvement in his health.
small and not important or not serious
We’ve made some minor changes to the program.
small – used about places, buildings etc in which space is used effectively, or about phones, cameras, cars etc which are designed to be much smaller than usual
It is a pleasant and compact city.
used about a room, house etc that is too small
used about a space, room, or vehicle that is too small because people do not have enough room to move around
They all lived together in a cramped apartment.
The car feels cramped with four adults in it.
very small – used about objects, numbers, or amounts
Dairy foods provide your body with a tiny amount of vitamin D.
I’ll just have a teeny bit of cream.
There’s just one teeny little problem.
extremely small and extremely difficult to see or notice
They found minute traces of poison in his body.
a miniature camera, watch, railway etc is made in a very small size. A miniature horse, dog etc is bred to be a very small size
The spy used a miniature camera.
extremely small and impossible to see without special equipment
extremely small in a surprising way
She was wearing a minuscule bikini.
The threat from terrorism is minuscule compared to other risks in our lives.
An itty-bitty little bug crawled across his forehead.
We stayed at some itty-bitty hotel in a back street.
small.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: not large in size or amount
small.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Boeing doesn’t make a small, 100-seat plane.
The recent fare increases are small.
For a small fee, we can sell your shares for you.
small.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: unimportant or easy to deal with
small.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The company has admitted to small mistakes in billing.
It would be a small matter to offer employees interest-free loans for a limited period.
